Successful fabrication of Mn-based 3D-printed monoliths by stereolithography (SLA) is reported for the first-time in this work. The catalytic performances, as function of the surface composition, of the developed monoliths were evaluated by the total oxidation of toluene. The monolith with a surface composition of Mn0.7Ce0.3 showed the highest catalytic efficiency (98%) with a T90 value of 322 °C and acceptable catalytic stability after a second reaction cycle. By changing space velocity values, the T90 value can decrease to 311 °C. Microstructural and surface characterizations confirm the formation of Mn2O3 and Ce species on Mn sites and the homogeneous dispersion of Mn and Ce species on the surface of the 3D-printed monoliths. For comparison purposes, a single MnO X and CeO X monoliths were also synthesized and tested by toluene total oxidation, which confirms the cooperative effect between the oxygen storage capacity of Ce and the redox ability of Mn species observed in Mn0.7Ce0.3 monolith catalyst, giving rise to the highest catalytic activity. These results pointed out the promising catalytic properties of the developed Mn-based 3D-printed monolith catalysts for the total oxidation of volatile organic compounds at a low cost, which is an interesting alternative to mitigating atmospheric emissions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Mn-based 3D printing Monolith Stereolithography Catalytic oxidation Atmospheric Emissions Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Currently, air pollution is a concern worldwide because it is widely recognized as a huge issue for human health [1] and economic development [2,3]. According to the world health organization (WHO), in 2012, approximately 11.6% of deaths in the world were related to poor air quality [4]. It is well known that volatile organic compounds (VOCs), such as benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, xylene, etc., are the main hazardous pollutants. Their carcinogenic effects and atmospheric emissions forming secondary pollutants, such as ozone and fine particles [5], are related to respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, disrupting the nervous and reproductive systems, and cancer [1]. Usually, these hazardous compounds are generated from burning fuels and solvents [6,7,8]. Owing to the above reasons, different governments have strengthened their regulations for VOC emissions. However, according to WHO, in 2019, approximately 99% of the world's population lived in polluted environments [9]. There are different alternatives to mitigate VOC emissions, and catalytic oxidation is the most used technique owing to its high efficiency [10], low operation temperatures [11], and rapid conversion to less hazardous compounds. Until now, noble metals have been widely used for toluene catalytic oxidation [8,10,12]. However, more recently, the use of monometallic and bimetallic oxides based on transition metals has increased [13,14,15] owing to their low cost, high catalytic activity, and high poisoning resistance. Among these compounds, manganese oxides have been widely studied because of their interesting redox properties and different reactivity, which are greatly related to their crystalline phase. In this regard, it is reported that crystalline Mn3O4 gives rise to higher catalytic activity than Mn2O3, followed by MnO2 and MnO, which could be attributed to the ratio between oxidized and reductive species of Mn [16–18]. Furthermore, MnCeO x , a bimetallic oxide, has been reported as an excellent catalyst for toluene oxidation since it displays the temperature at 90% conversion (T90 values) within the range of 210 °C–246 °C [11,14] and T90 values around 244 °C for benzene [19], which are significantly lower than that of 275 °C and 270 °C reported in previous studies for monometallic MnO X catalyst [17,18]. These reports, despite that confirms the good activity of MnCeOX catalysts, were carried out by using powder catalysts, the application of powder catalysts implies several limitations on real applications, the most common are increase of the pressure drops and less workability. In the field of heterogeneous catalysis, new alternatives have been arising, such as the 3D printing technique, which has taken huge relevance in the last years owing to its optimization in the required amount of raw materials for the development of monoliths, the facility to promote the active sites on the monolith [20], its better geometry design [21], and the low operation costs [20]. For these reasons, in the last years, several catalysts with different applications, including mitigation of atmospheric emissions [21,22], removal of hazardous pollutants in wastewater [20], and production of chemical compounds [23–25], have been prepared by 3D printing. To our knowledge, very few reports have been published about the 3D-printed monoliths applied in the catalytic oxidation of VOCs, particularly toluene. Among them, Davo-Quiñonero et al. reported an improvement in the CO oxidation in excess oxygen just by 3D-printed monoliths with asymmetrical channels, attributed to the prevailing turbulent regime of gasses [22]. Rokicinska et al. [26] reported the total oxidation of toluene at 325 °C using a 3D-printed template of α-Al2O3 covered by Mobil five-type (MFI) zeolite layers and Co3O4. Authors suggest commercializing the prepared monoliths because of their facile preparation methodology [26]. In another work, Xi et al. [27] reported two methodologies for preparing Co3O4/SiO2 3D-printed monoliths. The first one consisted of the simultaneous printing of the support and the active site, while the second one included the 3D printing of the support followed by the loading of the active components. The results showed that the latter gave rise to the highest catalytic performances since more abundant Co3+ species and lattice oxygen are presented in this monolith, resulting in T90 values of toluene conversion within the range of 305 °C–458 °C [27]. Finally, Yao et al. [28] reported T90 values around 236 °C using a monolithic-ordered mesoporous-Co3O4@SiO2–S catalyst, which was treated with aluminum phosphate as a binder. This catalyst was prepared by 3D-ordered mesoporous templates using 3D printing technology [28]. In this work, to the best of our knowledge, the development and characterization of Mn-based monolith catalysts are reported for the first-time by the stereolithography (SLA) 3D-printing technique to produce asymmetrical channels. It is reported that SLA allows the production of complex geometric with reduced time and cost with better resolution, accuracy and surface finish compared the traditional materials extrusion technology [29]. In addition, the effect of the surface composition on their catalytic activity in the total oxidation of toluene, which is one of the most emitted VOC compounds, contributing to the formation of secondary organic aerosols (SOA) [30], is reported. 2 Methodology 2.1 Development of monolithic catalysts The 3D-printed monolith catalysts were designed using computer-aided design software with different channel arrangements to promote a turbulent flow to increase the contact between the surface of the catalyst and the flow pollutant [22]. Thus, the final design of the monoliths consisted of a cylinder with 0.645 mm in diameter and 13 mm large. The monoliths contained 16 square channels measuring 0.7 mm × 0.7 mm. These channels were designed to promote a turbulent flow with a transitional conversion between the input (square) and output (circular) channels. The number of channels was selected to achieve a value of 650 of channel per square inch (CPSI) which a similar value to real applications (200 – 800 CPSI). In addition, each channel was crossed horizontally by 11 circular channels along the walls to enhance the specific surface area. Then, the designed monoliths were printed by a stereolithography (SLA) technique (Form 3, Formlabs, Inc.). To print all monoliths, a new Mn-based ink was prepared using a photopolymer resin, White V4 Formlabs™, mixed with different amounts of Mn3O4 powder (≤ 99%, Sigma-Aldrich). These obtained monoliths are denoted as MnOX-based monoliths (green monolith). 2.2 Surface hydrothermal impregnation of printed monoliths Once the MnOX-based monoliths (green monoliths) were printed, the concentration of the active phase on the surface was impregnated by hydrothermal synthesis. For this, three different catalysts were impregnated with MnOX, CeOX, and Mn0.7Ce0.3 following a similar methodology than in our previous report [31]. It is worth mentioning that Mn0.7Ce0.3 was selected because of its better catalytic activity after several Mn/Ce ratios previously reported by our group [31]. For the hydrothermal impregnation, the MnOX-based catalyst was placed into a Teflon-lined hydrothermal autoclave reactor and filled with Mn(NO3)2·4H2O and/or Ce(NO3)3·6H2O solutions to impregnate 0.035 mol of each metal as MnOx, CeOX or 0.035 mol of the sum of both metals to prepare Mn0.7Ce0.3 solid solution on each monolith. Then, several drops of NH4OH were added to reach a pH of 8.7. Once the pH reached, the Teflon-lined hydrothermal autoclave reactors were thermally treated at 180 °C for 24 h. Finally, the three MnOx, CeOX, and Mn0.7Ce0.3 impregnated on MnOX-based monoliths (Green monoliths) were thermally treated at 340 °C for 1 h with a heating rate of 2 °C · min−1. The obtained monolith catalysts will be denoted as MnOX, CeOX, and Mn0.7Ce0.3, depending on the impregnated compounds. 2.3 Characterization of impregnated monoliths The crystalline phases, of the thermally treated monoliths, were identified by X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) using a Panalytical Empyrean Diffractometer at 40 kV and 30 mA with Ni-filter and Cu-Kα radiation (1.5414 Å). All the analyses were performed under room temperature and humidity between 20°–80° of 2θ with a step size of 0.026°. Additional analysis was also carried out from 26°–31° of 2θ with a smaller step size of 0.012° to evaluate any significant shift in the peak associated with the plane (111) from CeO2. It is worth mentioning that XRD assays were carried out under both thermally treated monoliths and powders obtained after milled the monoliths in order to be more representative, no significant different was observed in 2θ degree. Then, the channel size, shape, and chemical elemental composition on the surface of the monoliths were analyzed by scanning electron microscopy coupled energy-dispersive X-Ray spectroscopy (SEM-EDS) using a JEOL 6490LV coupled INCA-X detector. The surface composition was also investigated by Raman spectroscopy, analysis was carried out on monolith catalysts (at least 5 different zones of each monolith) and powders (milled monoliths) using a Jasco NRS-5100 in the range from 100 to 1800 cm–1 with an excitation source of 785 nm and resolution of 1 cm–1. Selected Raman spectra were chosen based on the most representative spectra appearing in monolith and powders catalysts. The chemical species was identified in monolithic catalysts by X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using a Thermo ESCALAB250 electron spectrometer with a monochromatized Al Kα X-Ray source (1486.6 eV) and a passing energy of 40 eV. The values of Ce (Ce3+/Ce4+), Mn (Mn3+/Mn4+), and oxygen species were obtained by deconvolution using a Gaussian-Lorentzian method. 2.4 Catalytic activity of monolith catalysts in toluene oxidation The catalytic activity of the 3D-printed monoliths was evaluated in toluene oxidation from room temperature to 330 °C. Several monoliths were well packed into a U-shape quartz microreactor and reacted with 1500 ppm of toluene (C7H8) in dry air with a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 35,000 mL · g–1 · h–1. The concentrations of CO and CO2 were continuously measured by a non-dispersive infrared continuous gas analyzer (ABB AO2020 with URAS 26 coupled module). The total toluene conversion to CO2 was calculated by Eq. (1). (1) Toluene Conversion ( % ) = C O 2 out − C O 2 in 10 , 500 × 100 Turnover Frequency (TOF) was calculated at 276 °C as reported in [32] by using Eq. (2). (2) T O F M n = ( X T o l u e n e ) ( V T o l u e n e ) m M / M W M Where: XToluene = Toluene conversion VToluene = Flow rate of toluene (mol.s − 1) mM = Weight of the surface active site (Mn3+)* used in the catalytic reaction (g) MWM = Atomic weight of the metal (Mn) *Calculated by the percentage composition of surface Mn3+ calculated from Mn total species (EDS) times Mn3+ ratio (XPS). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Fabrication of Mn-based 3D printed monoliths Fig. 1 shows images of the 3D-printed monoliths. Fig. 1a shows an image of the green monolith obtained after printing using a mixed solution with commercial ink and Mn3O4 powder. After several optimization tests, the ink composition with 1 wt% of Mn3O4 mixed with anionic surfactant was selected based on the printable capacity. A brown monolith is observed, indicating the presence of some Mn phase in the structure of the material. Fig. 1b shows an image of the monolith obtained after the impregnation with MnO X by hydrothermal treatment. In this monolith, a homogenous brown film is identified on the surface of the monolith, which can be attributed to the formation of the MnO X phase. Fig. 1c shows an image of the thermally treated monolith, in which no visible detached MnO X film was detected, suggesting an interaction between the previous Mn3O4-containing ink and the MnO X film deposited on the surface of the monolith after the hydrothermal treatment. Moreover, the Mn or Ce surface content of the monolith was analyzed by SEM–EDS and XPS analysis, as will be presented in the next section. Finally, the asymmetry design of channels in the 3D printed monoliths is shown in Fig. 1d, revealing a square shape that is changed to a circular through the channel. This transformation was carried out to promote turbulence inside the monolith channels. 3.2 Characterization of Mn-based 3D printing monoliths The crystalline structure of the monoliths was analyzed by XRD. Fig. 2 shows X-Ray Diffractograms for representative samples obtained for the prepared monoliths, including green monolith and MnOX, CeOX, and Mn0.7Ce0.3 impregnated monoliths. No substantial difference in the crystalline phases was observed between monoliths and powders (milled monoliths). Fig. 2a shows the general diffractogram, in which two different crystalline phases of MnO X could be first identified for the green monolith. The peaks observed at 2θ of 28.83, 31.02, 32.30, 36.03, 44.46, 50.65, 58.51 and 59.82o are attributed to the planes (112), (200), (103), (211), (220), (105), (321), and (224), respectively, which are associated to the Mn3O4 phase (JCPDS No.00–024–0734), as expected [18], indicating the successful incorporation of Mn3O4 powders with the commercial ink after 3D printing. In addition, low-intensity peaks at 2θ of 28.85, 56.61, and 57.40° are observed, which are attributed to the planes (110), (211), and (121) of the crystalline MnO2 phase (JCPDS No.00–050–0866), respectively. The existence of this phase could be attributed to some MnO2 impurities in the commercial Mn3O4 powder. Finally, different peaks attributed to the chemical composition of the commercial ink identified as C.I. are also observed, such as inert SiO2, TiO2, etc. Moreover, Fig. 2a shows the X-Ray diffractogram of the MnO X -impregnated monolith (denoted as MnO X ), in which the MnO X phase was incorporated by hydrothermal synthesis compared with the green monolith. Two different crystalline phases of manganese oxides are observed, maintaining the existence of a mixed oxide with Mn3O4 and MnO2 phases. This diffractogram suggests that the hydrothermal process used to synthesize MnO X -impregnated monolith increases the crystallinity of both MnOX phases by 57%, deduced from the higher area of the peaks at 36.03° and 28.85° (attributed to Mn3O4 and MnO2, respectively) compared with the green monolith. The preservation of the Mn3O4 crystalline phase is important because, according to previous literature, this crystalline phase showed the best catalytic activity in the oxidation of toluene using monoliths or powders [16–18]. In the monoliths containing Ce (CeO X and Mn0.7Ce0.3), several peaks attributed to the crystalline phase of CeO2 (JCPDS No.01–080–3865) are observed at 2θ of 28.50, 33.03, 47.40, 56.25, and 58.99o, which are associated to the planes (111), (200), (220), (311), and (222), respectively [11,15,30]. Both samples also showed the above-mentioned peaks attributed to the crystalline Mn3O4 phase, suggesting the presence of Mn3O4–CeO2 mixed oxides on the surface of the monoliths. It is worth mentioning that the peaks attributed to the crystalline CeO2 phase prevail in the diffractogram of Mn0.7Ce0.3-impregnated monolith synthesized by hydrothermal synthesis of solid solution Mn0.7Ce0.3O X compared with the green monolith. However, by the diffractograms shown in Fig. 2b, corresponding to a zoom-in image of the plane (111) under a smaller step size, it is possible to observe a clear shift to lower angles of 2θ. This slight shift is attributed to the structural distortion produced by the incorporation of Mn species (Mn2+ = 0.80 Å, Mn3+ = 0.65 Å, Mn4+ = 0.53 Å) into Ce sites (Ce4+ = 0.94 Å, Ce3+ = 1.11 Å) [33–36]. The formation of this solid solution is of great interest because it is accompanied by the generation of structural defects, such as oxygen vacancies, which potentially enhance oxygen mobility because of catalytic activity [11,14,19,34,37]. It is worth mentioning that the catalyst identified as Mn0.7Ce0.3 has a mixed of crystalline phases, in one side the formation of Mn3O4 and, on the other side the formation of the solid solution Mn-Ce-OX with cubic structures formed by Mn species occupying Ce sites. From the above results, it is possible to conclude the successful synthesis of 3D printed monoliths with MnO X incorporated into the structural composition, which is enhanced by the hydrothermal incorporation of MnOX, CeOX, or Mn0.7Ce0.3. Those hydrothermally treated samples showed the formation of MnO X , CeO X , or Mn0.7Ce0.3OX as expected, with clear evidence of solid solution formation by the shift in the diffractograms. Furthermore, the channel shape and size and the elemental chemical composition of each 3D-printed monolith were analyzed by SEM–EDS. It is worth mentioning that all prepared monoliths showed a 25% shrinkage after the thermal treatment, similar to the literature [23,38–40]. Fig. 3 shows the micrographs of each printed monolith. Fig. 3a shows the green monolith with a homogeneous distribution of Mn along the surface. This image confirms the successful Mn incorporation into the structure of the printed monolith, as discussed previously. An apparent increase in the Mn surface concentration is observed in Fig. 3b for sample MnO X , which corresponds to the green monolith impregnated with MnO X by hydrothermal synthesis. This increase is confirmed by data shown in Table 1 , which exposes an average of EDS-mapping analysis, from 4.80 to 31.7 wt%. Fig. 3c and 3d show the Mn-based 3D-printed monoliths impregnated with CeO X and Mn0.7Ce0.3, respectively, prepared by the hydrothermal method. As shown in Table 1, the monolith identified as CeO X (just impregnated by CeO X ) shows a very low concentration of Mn on the surface (1.30 wt%.) and a very high concentration of Ce above 40%wt. This result confirms the successful impregnation of CeO X on green monolith after hydrothermal synthesis and the existence of the surface Mn corresponding to the Mn content in the chemical structure of the 3D-printed monolith (green monolith). Finally, the sample identified as Mn0.7Ce0.3 shows a homogenous distribution on the surface of Mn and Ce. According to Table 1, the content of Mn and Ce for this sample is 11.4 wt% and 33.7 wt%. These results can be an indication of the successful migration of Ce to the surface of the impregnated monoliths. Surface characterization was performed by Raman and XPS. Fig. 4 shows Raman spectra of all prepared monoliths. The sample identified as MnO X shows a clear peak at 658 cm–1, which is attributed to the A1g mode from the Mn–O breathing vibration of divalent manganese ions in tetrahedral coordination in commercial hausmannite Mn3O4 [41]. Two additional peaks are observed at 316 and 370 cm–1 with a weak peak at 480 cm–1, which are associated with the Mn3O4 crystalline phase [41], confirming the existence of Mn3O4 on the surface of the monolith. Fig. 4 also shows the Raman spectra of the Mn0.7Ce0.3-impregnated monolith. Similar peaks are observed with slight shifts to lower frequencies, which could be attributed to the structure distortion produced by substituting Mn species in Ce sites [14,34] which agrees very well with XRD results shown in Fig. 1. In addition, a peak at 461 cm–1 is observed, which is attributed to the F2g mode of symmetrical stretching vibration resulting from the O atoms around Ce4+ ions in the CeO2 fluorite structure [14,35,42]. As expected, the latter is also observed in the monolith identified as CeO X . Moreover, a low-intense broad signal at 600 cm–1 attributed to the existence of defects in the crystalline structure of CeO2 is observed for this sample [14]. It was reported that defects could be beneficial to adsorb and activate oxygen, which is recognized as a key factor in oxidation reactions [14]. From these results, we can confirm the formation of different phases of Mn3O4, CeO2, and a solid solution of Mn–Ce oxides on the surface monoliths denoted as MnO X , CeO X , and Mn0.7Ce0.3, respectively. These results agree with the XRD ones observed in Fig. 2. Fig. 5 shows the XPS results of all prepared monoliths. Fig. 5a shows the Mn 2p region where three clear peaks are identified at 640.8, 641.9, and 643.1 eV, which can be attributed to Mn2+, Mn3+, and Mn4+species, respectively [43]. Despite the similarity in the spectra, the binding energy and intensity of each peak are not identical. As expected, the sample identified as MnO X shows the highest intensity compared to other monoliths. In addition, this MnOX-impregnated monolith exhibits lower binding energy, which increases as a function of ceria content as follows: MnO X < Mn0.7Ce0.3 < CeO X . This trend is evidence of the interactions among Mn–Ce–O monoliths [14], higher in monoliths with Ce incorporated into the structural oxide composition, as previously reported in the literature [44]. Table 2 shows the Mn4+/Mnn+ ratio, where low values are identified in all samples as expected, attributed to the existence of reduced species Mn2+ and Mn3+ in Mn3O4. These results agree with the crystalline phases identified in Fig. 2 and the Raman spectra in Fig. 4. This trend of the Mn4+/Mnn+ ratio suggests that the addition of Ce promotes the prevalence of reduced Mn species. Furthermore, Fig. 5b shows the O 1 s region of all prepared monoliths. Three well-defined peaks are observed at 533.6, 531.3, and 529.3 eV, which can be attributed to adsorbed OH species, adsorbed oxygen species (Oads), and lattice oxygen species (Olat), respectively [19,35,45]. A high-intense narrow peak is also observed at 529.3 eV in the monolith identified as CeO X and MnO X , which can be attributed to the lattice oxygen of CeO2 and Mn3O4/MnO2, respectively, according to X-Ray diffractograms shown in Fig. 2. This behavior is changed in the Mn0.7Ce0.3 monolith where the intensity and peak areas at 529.3 and 531.3 eV increases significantly. In addition, as expected, the Oads/Olat ratios shown in Table 2 confirm the higher concentration of the Oads species in the CeO X monolith, which is associated with the oxygen storage capacity of Ce as an intrinsic property [46]. By comparison of the Oads/Olat ratios among three monoliths shown in Table 2, it is feasible to conclude that Ce contributes to the formation of Oads species in CeO X and Mn0.7Ce0.3 monoliths, making MnO X with the less Oads/Olat ratio as expected. Finally, Fig. 5c shows the XPS spectra of the Ce 3d region, identifying u and v peaks attributed to the spin 3d 3/2 and 3d5/2, respectively. From this Fig. 5c, it is possible to identify v, v1, v3, u, u1, and u3 peaks at 916.46, 910.42, 900.68, 898.1, 888.6, and 882.1 eV, respectively, which are attributed to Ce4+ species. The peaks identified as v2 and u2 are assigned to Ce3+ species [11,19,47]. In these spectra, a higher intensity is observed in the monolith identified as CeO x , and Ce3+ and Ce4+ species coexist in both Mn0.7Ce0.3 and CeOX. Furthermore, Table 2 shows higher values of the Ce4+/Ce3+ ratio for the monolith identified as CeO X , which agrees with the crystalline phase CeO2 identified for this monolith in Fig. 2 3.3 Catalytic oxidation of toluene with Mn-based 3D-printed monoliths 3.3.1 Catalytic performance All prepared monoliths were tested in the total catalytic oxidation of toluene. Fig. 6 a shows the total conversion of toluene from room temperature to 330 °C. From this Figure, a possible complete conversion (98%) is observed for the Mn0.7Ce0.3-impregnated monolith catalyst, which is the monolith that has the highest catalytic activity. A T90 value at 322 °C is observed for this Mn0.7Ce0.3-impregnated monolith catalyst (Table 3 ), which agrees with the results obtained by Rokicinska et al. [26] for 3D-printed templates of α-Al2O3 covered by MFI zeolite layers and Co3O4 (T90 value of 325 °C) and Xi et al. [27] for Co3O4/SiO2 3D-printed monoliths (T90 values in the range of 305 °C – 458 °C). Thus, it is worth mentioning that the catalytic activity shown in Fig. 6a is competitive among different monolith conversions previously reported in the literature [18,48–51]. In addition, turnover frequencies (TOF) were calculated at 276 °C for each catalyst (≈T10). Turnover frequency per number of the surface-active site Mn3+ (TOFMn) value obtained for MnOX, Mn0.7Ce0.3 and CeOX are 0.0087, 0.089 and 0.25 s − 1 respectively. These TOFMn values agree very well with the catalytic activity of each catalyst at low temperatures (≈T10) as shown in Fig. 6a. In addition, these TOF values are in the same range as data reported by Mn and noble metals [8,52]. According to Tables 1 and 2, it is possible to identify abundant reduced Mn3+ species in Mn0.7Ce0.3 catalyst. These Mn3+ species have been considered the main actives sites during the total oxidation of toluene [34] which are enhanced by surface Olat, species also abundant in Mn0.7Ce0.3 catalyst, whose mobility is promoted by the formation of Ce3+ species (as it is observed in Table 2), resulting in its better catalytic activity as shown in Fig. 6. The higher catalytic performance of the Mn0.7Ce0.3-impregnated monolith catalyst can be attributed to the cooperative effect between the oxygen storage capacity of the Ce species and the redox properties of Mn. This cooperative effect is confirmed by the Oads/Olat ratios shown in Table 2 and by analyzing the catalytic behavior among all synthesized monoliths. Moreover, an interesting behavior is observed between MnO X and CeO X monoliths. For CeO X monoliths, the toluene conversion begins at 220 °C, reaching 40% of conversion at 330 °C, ending the reaction. However, the MnO X monolith begins the conversion at a higher temperature (260 °C), reaching 33% of conversion at the end of the reaction at 330 °C. Fig. 6a confirms the effect of Ce addition in the monoliths promoting the oxygen storage capacity and increasing the oxygen mobility and the amount of the Oads species, as shown in Table 2. These afore-mentioned catalytic properties agree with the lower starting temperature conversion at 220 °C for CeO X compared with MnO X [53,54]. Fig. 6b shows the CO formation in ppm. For CeO X -impregnated monolith catalysts, 600 ppm of CO is the highest amount of CO formed, as shown in Fig. 6b, representing only 5.7% of selectivity. Nevertheless, the CO formation for Mn0.7Ce0.3 impregnated monolith catalyst was lower; >50 ppm at the beginning of the reaction at above 270 °C, the highest CO formation was 244 ppm when the temperature reached 315 °C, and then a significant drop was observed, which agree with the rapid increase in the toluene conversion, as shown in Fig. 6a. This behavior can be attributed to the oxygen migration from the lattice to the surface being the driving force and the bulk-surface gradient of oxygen in the catalyst [55,48], which can be promoted by the interaction between Mn–Ce in the solid solution of Mn0.7Ce0.3-impregnated monolith, which is not observed either for CeO x - or MnO X -impregnated monoliths. 3.3.2 Stability tests After the catalytic conversion reactions, stability tests were performed, as shown in Fig. 7 . Fig. 7a shows toluene catalytic conversion during two consecutive reaction cycles with a 30% decrease in the total conversion of toluene after the second reaction cycle. This decrease can be associated with the interaction between the polymer from the ink composition and the active Mn sites of the catalyst. Further studies will be reported in the future with SLA printing technologies to justify this hypothesis. Nevertheless, to evaluate this possible interaction as a function of time, Fig. 7b shows the stability test after the second cycle at 50% of conversion for 5 h. It is worth mentioning that no decrease in the toluene conversion was detected, which can be considered evidence that the monoliths can reach stability after the second reaction cycle. 3.3.3 Effect of the WHSV In real applications, space velocity can be considered as a crucial value for catalytic reactions. Fig. 8 shows the effect of WHSV variations at 17,500, 35,000, and 65,000 mL·g–1·h–1, by changing the number of monoliths during the rection. Evident changes in temperature conversions are observed from the T90 values decrease from 322 °C to 311 °C at 35,000 and 17,500 mL·g–1·h–1, respectively. Table 3 shows the T10, T50, and T90 values, where an interesting decrease at lower WHSV is observed as expected. These findings confirm a positive correlation between toluene retention time and catalytic activity. Fig. 8 also demonstrates that WHSV values below than 35,000 mL·g–1·h–1 are the better velocities to high conversion of toluene at temperatures below 330 °C. From these results, it is possible to conclude that the Mn-based 3D-printed monoliths reported in this work can be competitive to perform in the total catalytic oxidation of toluene using an appropriate WHSV. Table 4 shows comparative results among different monolithic catalysts reported in literature. In this table is possible to identify the competitive activity of the Mn0.7Ce0.3 monolith against previous reports, mainly at high conversions. This Table shows T80 and T90 values at 339 and 348 °C, respectively reported in literature [49,56] while the T90 value obtained in this work is 319 °C. In addition, from Fig. 6a is possible to identify an approximate value near to T100 at 322 °C which a competitive result as mentioned in Table 4. This Table 4 also demonstrates that under similar WHSV, the T90 value decreases to 311 °C which is very competitive with previous reports [57]. Finally, it is worth mentioning the effect of the toluene concentration (Co Toluene), in this work the Co Toluene is 1500 ppm which is higher than reports in Table 4. According to previous literature a difference in C0 Toluene from 500 to 1500 ppm, can reach up to 50 °C higher in T10 for the higher concentration and 10 °C in T90 [58]. 4 Conclusions Mn-based 3D-printed monoliths were successfully prepared for the first-time using SLA printing technologies. All prepared monoliths showed catalytic activity in the total oxidation of toluene. The catalytic activity of the prepared monoliths is enhanced by the impregnation of MnO X , CeO X , and Mn0.7Ce0.3 phases, which were incorporated by hydrothermal synthesis on the surface of MnOX-based monolith (denoted green monolith). All samples were tested and showed catalytic activity in the total oxidation of toluene. The monolith impregnated by the solid solution Mn0.7Ce0.3 showed the best catalytic activity >98%. This catalytic activity was attributed to the cooperative effect between the oxygen storage capacity of Ce and the redox properties of MnOX. The Mn3+ species were identified as the main active sites, enhanced by surface Olat species whose mobility is promoted by the formation Ce3+ species, resulting in a better catalytic activity. This monolith showed a 30% decrease in the total conversion after the second reaction cycle, being stable for 5 h after the second reaction cycle. Therefore, this work proposes, for the first-time, the fabrication of 3D-printed Mn-based monoliths by SLA technologies with a potential application in the total oxidation of VOCs as a low-cost alternative to atmospheric emissions removal. Additional experimentation should be performed to improve the catalytic activity since the monolith design includes the enhancement of the active sites. CRediT authorship contribution statement J.F. coredata.dc:description: Successful fabrication of Mn-based 3D-printed monoliths by stereolithography (SLA) is reported for the first-time in this work. The catalytic performances, as function of the surface composition, of the developed monoliths were evaluated by the total oxidation of toluene. The monolith with a surface composition of Mn0.7Ce0.3 showed the highest catalytic efficiency (98%) with a T90 value of 322 °C and acceptable catalytic stability after a second reaction cycle. By changing space velocity values, the T90 value can decrease to 311 °C. Microstructural and surface characterizations confirm the formation of Mn2O3 and Ce species on Mn sites and the homogeneous dispersion of Mn and Ce species on the surface of the 3D-printed monoliths. For comparison purposes, a single MnO X and CeO X monoliths were also synthesized and tested by toluene total oxidation, which confirms the cooperative effect between the oxygen storage capacity of Ce and the redox ability of Mn species observed in Mn0.7Ce0.3 monolith catalyst, giving rise to the highest catalytic activity. These results pointed out the promising catalytic properties of the developed Mn-based 3D-printed monolith catalysts for the total oxidation of volatile organic compounds at a low cost, which is an interesting alternative to mitigating atmospheric emissions.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of the surface composition of MnOX-CeOX 3D-printed monolithic catalysts toward total oxidation of toluene.
